text: Erlend. Welcome.

Thanks for joining us in the AWS studio.
Thank you very much.
Happy to be here.

Want to tell us a little bit more
about your role at Working Group Two?
I am CEO of Working Group Two,

lead the company on a daily basis
and part of the founding team as well.

I think the origin story for Working
Group Two is fascinating.

Tell us a little bit
about how your company got its start.
So it's a long story.

It started almost as 
a skunkworks project inside of Telenor

Group, which is one of the big mobile
operators in the world.

It was partly a technical project,
and then I got involved in it

after having worked in Asia and I had
a very specific experience in Asia

where I was working with the Googles
and the Facebooks of the world.
And while I was inside Telenor,
the experience from

that was, every time we had a meeting,
the Googles and the Facebooks they had,

they brought an engineer,
they brought a product manager,
and they had built something...

They had fixed something
for the next meeting.

And we as an operator tended to,
maybe, have written a specification

that maybe our procurement department
had maybe talked with the supplier with.

And there was a very tangible difference
in speed of innovation.
And I think over time that accumulates to

that the industry
is going to be very challenged.
That frustrated me.

I met my co-founder, Werner Eriksson,
who's the CTO.

He was building what was then
called Software Telco, which is basically

a software-is-eating-the-world
version of a mobile core network.

We spun that
out of Telenor into a separate company,

and for the last five years
we have been building

mobile core
as a global programmable platform.

So let's dive a little bit deeper into the
evolution of mobile core as a service.

We were talking earlier about this idea
of transformation pressures for telcos.
Help me understand that better

in the context of mobile cores
and what you were seeing from customers.
I think core is
most underutilized,

the most ignored part of a mobile
network. It is not your biggest cost.

Radio networks are always going
to be the biggest cost

for mobile operators, but core, in a way,
is where the magic happens.

It's where you go from,
you know, bits and bytes into services.
And I
think what's happened over the last three

or four decades is
the industry has focused on cost
and the way to drive down cost in
core has been to make every box

by any vendor replaceable
with any other box from any other vendor.

And what this has led to
is massive complexity,

because you have typically many,
many different vendors in your network.

Every box has to work
with every other box in the world.

So the boxes themselves
become incredibly complex,

and then you have many boxes,
and that complexity becomes overwhelming.

And then in addition, you have 2G, 3G, 4G,
and now we have 5G.
You have
CS voice, you have IMS, you have SMS

over this generation, SMS or data.
The complexity becomes overwhelming.
So core has become a bottleneck.
It's become a cost item.

I haven't almost heard from any operator
that loves their core.

Everybody sees it as a pain point
and as a cost item,

as an inhibitor
to innovation.
Core networks

is almost like a broken industry
and it needs to be fixed

because it's actually
a source of innovation

and product
development and value creation.
But that's not what it is today.

So that's
what we were on a mission to change

and I think we're seeing that
that's possible to do.

Building on your mission,
do you think that the cloud can help

operators
fall in love again with the mobile core?
I think absolutely.
The cloud enables

a couple of things, it enables
small teams to do very big things.

And that's
where our cloud journey started.
We started actually using OpenStack

and we found that we're spending
half our teams time managing,

you know, hardware
and virtualization platforms.

And we shifted to AWS
seven years ago now.

We've been sitting on AWS for
seven years building a cloud native core.

So they allowed a very small team
to do very big things.

I think that's the
first thing that cloud does.

The second thing is it's like standing
on the shoulders of giants, right?

You have some really spectacular
security services.

You have managed databases,
you have any number of things

that we would have to stand up
big, separate teams to do.
And relying on that allows us to become

very professional and be very secure
and have a lot of flexibility

that would otherwise
take hundreds of people to do.
The third thing it does

is that it allows you to do things
at global scale.

So in the scheme of the industry,
we're a fairly small company,

but we're actually live across the globe
and we're spinning up in different regions.

And we're now spinning up
in the new region,

we have a terra-
formed all our infrastructure

and in days,
we have new cores up and standing.

That global consistency
suddenly allows you to do one thing

at global scale, which was very,
very hard to do previously.

Those are just some of the things
that we we really deeply leverage
with cloud and AWS.

I want to dive a little deeper
into your cloud transformation

journey with AWS.
What was your experience?

You mentioned a lot of the services and
partner solutions, the likes of TerraForm.

What's been your experience on AWS, their
specific services that have made

your journey remarkably effective
or cost effective, scalable?
Any number of them.

So there's a large
number of them that we use.
I think things like GuardDuty.

Trying to replicate GuardDuty
at small scale
I think is, if not impossible,

you're going to have to have a very,
very big team to do it.
Things like managed Kafka, managed RDS,

you can do them on your own,
but then suddenly you have a team

that has to do that, which it has,
you know, a big alternative
cost for us.

I think we
have a kind of a list of the services

that we use and it's extensive,
but a lot of it is around.

We can move faster,
we can offload the teams

so that they can focus on where we can
create value as opposed to managing

not basic stuff, but stuff
that we don't really want to focus on.

We can focus on the application
and we can use a managed database,
for example.
If we had to have three people

building a managed database,
that's that's has a very high cost for us.

So it speed, its flexibility, and then these
services are good. They work really well.
Right?

Resiliency is a huge thing
for us, running core networks.

So getting managed services
that automatically work across regions,

that have in-built resiliency
and redundancy, that's powerful for us.

So through the speed and agility,
you can start to develop
your own value added services.

We talked a little bit
about beyond the mobile core

opportunities in IoT and mobile
private networks.

Tell me a little bit
more about your solution suite.
So we have a kind of a fundamental

philosophy about this, and then there's
a resulting large set of use cases.

So in a way, I think we're inspired by AWS
in this regard.
If you're leveraging S3 or EC2,

the smallest start up in the world
can go in
with a credit card and use S3.

Citibank, you know,
one of the biggest companies in the world,
will use the same S3 API.

And the same for EC2 and the same
for almost every other AWS service.

Now, the use case they use it for,
you don't know about this

actually, that they can use it
for a lot of different things.

We're building the mobile core
with the same mindset.

We think that if it's a private network
for 10 SIMs, or if it's an MNO
network for 10 million SIMs,

a lot of the technology
is actually the same.
The security should be the same.

The scale, of course,
is different,

and the complexity of services
can be slightly different.

If it's a data
only private network

and if it's a full MNO Core,
they are different.

But actually,
your user databases are the same,

your packet gateways
are the same, etc., etc..

We're building this with the mindset
of a hyperscaler, that we're building
common infrastructure

where you can choose both the scale
at which you want to do things

and the depth of the services
that you want to use.
Out of

that comes everything from private
networks,

hybrid private and public networks,
IoT networks,

MVNOs, MVNEs, MVNAs, 
MVNX, and MNOs.

Because the basic functional technology
is actually the same
at the heart of the service,
it just has different incarnations.

And in our model,
we have a multi-tenant model,

which allows an operator
to actually even have

what will be perceived as different
networks for different use cases.
And they can

attach different management systems
and different applications on top of the networks.

I like how you mentioned that
different incarnations based on the same

underlying,
modular, scalable infrastructure.

Maybe we dive a little bit deeper
into one of the use cases.

Is there a disaster recovery as a service
play here?

We think that's
one of the really interesting ones

that we're looking quite closely into now,
which is...

I think the only thing
that you can be sure about networks

is that at some point
they're going to fail, unfortunately,
and both for ourselves and our customers,

we think disaster recovery
is a particularly interesting one,
partly because of the economic equation.

Having an empty network sitting somewhere
idle is a very expensive piece of kit.

But using cloud, you can have
as part of a broader platform,

you can actually very economically
have a disaster recovery.
That's one aspect of it.
It can be a very...

It's almost like a cheap insurance policy
that you can have standing.

The second part of it is, like we do now,
we operate out of three different regions
and we have, in one of our regions,

we have a fourth region
as a disaster recovery zone.

We can actually spin up in... 
Is it now 23 different regions

Amazon has now, something like that?
Something like that.

We could actually realistically spin up
in any region within hours.

And we
can also do a hot standby between regions.
So I think that the resiliency

and the disaster recovery
part of the story  is very

interesting. It's still early days,
for the product as such,
but it's a very interesting story to do.

Maybe let's fast forward for a second
as we look towards the future of mobile

core as a service, what's the next level
of Working Group Two on AWS?
What's that look like?

The current status in the world
is every operator in the world

basically deploy their own core
in their own specific way.

You have, you know,
a few hundred operators in the world

and you have an equal amount
of incarnations of different course.

Now, each of these operators
might be big in their own country,

but they're actually very subscale
in the context of big tech.
And it's very inefficient,
this way

of doing it, and it inhibits innovation
very powerfully.
So we think that

building this as platforms,
as global cores,

is actually going to change things
radically.

So as we think ten years from now
or give or take a few years,

we think you're going to see an evolution
to global mobile

core platforms to which operators
attach their radio networks.

Changing the whole model, really,
where you have a platform that is there
and you simply attach your radio network

and you get all the benefits
of that platform constantly.
That's the first part of it.

The second part of it is if you build it
that way,

you can realistically start
making these networks programmable.

You start exposing APIs
and you start building,
what we used to call Android for networks.

You basically build app stores
for networks.

And any developer in the world can, today,
come onto our platform,

build their product,
publish their product,
and any operator on the platform,

in a completely different country
can actually activate that product.

This business
model of platforms

reducing the cost of innovation
very close to zero,

we think that's the future
of mobile core networks.

So for enterprises and operators
looking to learn more about Working Group
Two, where should they turn to?
Yeah,

they can of course reach out to us
directly.
They can go to our website.

I think that's a good place to start,
they can reach us there

and then a contact form
and we'll be in touch very shortly.
Wonderful.

It's a great discussion here today Erlend.
Thanks for joining the studio.

I really appreciate your thoughts
and insights.

Thank you very much.
Thank you for having me.
